The IBM raises the ghost of tickets past
By MARC DUVOISIN
Having your car towed is like having
your kidney removed and held at $25
bail—they've got it, you need it, and you
gotta pay to get it back.
The incarceration of motor vehicles is a
relatively recent experiment in the
200-year history of the American penal
system; and an enormously successful
one. The practice was officially instituted
back in the forties by New York Mayor
Fiorello LaGuardia as a means of
controlling the growing traffic congestion
in his metropolis. It was, to say the least,
a horrible comeuppance for the suburban
commuter who would decide, say, to let
the meter run over an extra 10 minutes
while he was negotiating the price of that
bottle of Mateus, and return to find his
parking space vacant.
After the initial stage of thinking his
car stolen or lost, he realized what had
happened. And after the secondary stage
of outrage at having his vehicle abducted,
he began to think what a long walk it
would be back across the Hudson and,
like as not, took a bus downtown to pay
his dues. For about a decade, New York
devoted a full square mile on Welfare
Island to housing towed cars, so large
were the daily heists. Not only did the
traffic congestion get better, but the city
was able to avert God knows how many
budget deficits—all due to the towing
business.
Other cities took the cue therefrom
and,by that process we call specialization,
made the penalty of towing an effective
and fear-inspiring caveat. In metropolises
the world over, motorists avoid
"Tow-Away Zones" like the plague.
My own experience with the brigands
of the Baltimore Police Department was
only partially my fault. True, I had made
it a practice of allowing the rear end of
my 1971 gold Vega to protrude two or
three feet beyond the legal boundary on
Art Museum Drive—a discreet violation in
my view. But in the last analysis, it was
the computer that got me.
Like every other student motorist I
know, I accepted as gospel the fact that
you just don't pay out of state parking
violations. The states don't
reciprocate—everybody knows that.
Those Jersey plates were a free pass
through the insufferable tedium of petty
local parking tickets—or so I thought.
Like any astute out of state driver, I
had accumulated my fair share of
outdated parking fines, the thought never
entering my mind that I would someday
be forced to pay for all of them. The
police would no sooner enforce back
violations than they would rage through
the Charles Village arresting/ every soul
with a fleck of marijuana on his person.
You just don't do that.
But the Baltimore Police Department
has ushered in a new era in parking
violations—the end of innocence,
courtesy of their new computer: a
leviathan IBM (takes up to one-third of
the new central headquarters downtown,
according to one of the many policemen I
was to encounter) which can conduct
nationwide scans of motor vehicles
bureaus at a moment's notice. I was, I
suspect, one of its first victims.
While walking through campus one
morning last week discussing with a
friend our impending intersession
excursion to Mexico, I was accosted
by a breathless colleague: "Hurry up,
they're towing your car." I sprinted down
to Art Museum Drive to find the car
suspended from the maw of a large
orange towing rig, a small crowd of
curious passers-by watching as one Officer
C.L. Rummel affixed a parking citation

•

to the windshield.
"Excuse me," I interjected. "That's my
car."
"Nope. Mine now," replied the officer.
"How come?"
"Son,you've got a $117 due on this
car," Rummel explained, pulling out a
yellow print-out cataloguing a surfeit of
back violations next to my license plate
number. A new computer, he said, was
helping police track down out of state
violators.
Above my protestations, Rummel
insisted that the car would have to be
towed—impounded really—until the
violations were paid for. As the tow truck
pulled down Charles Street and out of
sight, friends and passers-by alike were

laughing, behind their rueful faces of
affected concern, at the total abjectness
of my situation. They were taking my
car—and I couldn't do anything about it.
Officer Rummel, however, acquitted
himself like a true servant of the public,
tabulating each and every back fine for
my benefit, and giving me the address of
the site of incarceration, and the parking
fine office. The final figure I owed,
towing and storage charges included, was
a staggering $117.
How to raise such a sum? I knew for
certain that all of the myriad fines
weren't my own—I had always been
liberal in lending out my car. So I decided
that the taxman would have to cometh to
the houses of a few of the more frequent

borrowers of the vehicle. To ne
avail—word of my unhappy circums,ance
must have spread quickly, for the most
logical offenders were either indisposed at
the time of my arrival of\"not home right
now.
Aidecj by a loan from a wealthy and
generous colleague, I set off downtown
the next day to lay claim to my property,
not without enlisting the company of a
particularly husky acquaintance. For the
address of the parking fine office-200
North Holiday Street—had made me
wary, as I was familiar enough with
downtown Baltimore to know that the
street names lose their significance once
one • gets to those low numbers. North
Gay Street, East Eager Street, Baltimore
Street-- after dark they all have the same
name—Certain Death.
Upon arrival, however, I saw that there
was little cause for concern. 200 North
Holiday Street is an immense federal
building which houses, almost as an
afterthought, portions of the Baltimore
Police administration. No hassle
whatsoever in paying up my parking
tickets and accrued late fines—the people
were all too happy to accept my money.
I was advised to get over to the impound
lot on the harbor and pay the towing fine
with dispatch, since the vehicle would
only be held there for three days.
Whether the car would be thrown into
the harbor at the end of that period, theY
would not specify.
Likewise at the impound lot, the
cashier was gratified to accept my check,
treating us to four ritual
mispronunciations of our grand
institution's name as she perused mY
Hopkins ID.
The dues paid, we got into the car and
embarked on the short sojourn up Charles
Street. As the block numbers went by.'
silently assessed the damages of tills
unexpected debacle: no new jacket this
winter, assorted entertainment
economies, and, most bitter pill of all. no
Mexico.
I did not, however, look at the 65,000
miles on the Vega's odometer, listen to
her ravaged muffler and ill-tinted
carburetor, and ask myself if paying the
fine required for her recovery had been
worth it.
You just don't do that.

Jogging with Jan

The finer points of road-running
By JAN HAMMERMAN
I first engaged in the activity of jogging
at age seven, upon catching sight of my
father with a belt in hand . This pioneer
effort failed miserably, however, because
my shoestrings were too long and because
Nature called at a most inopportune
moment. Be that as it may. My premier
attempt at competitive running also
proved somewhat less that successful—a
third-place finish to a shnoozer puppy
and the neighborhood para'plegic in the
annual Block party.
Unperturbed, undaunted, and slightly
crazy, I joined my high school
cross-country team with hopes of earning
a varsity letter to put on a cross-country
sweatshirt which would be worn over a
cross-country T-shirt. All three objectives
were realized. In addition, I cam? in
156th in Baltimore County, improving 3
notches after bringing up the rear a
season earlier.
Jogging demands that the participant
have two legs and as little common sense
as possible. The last feature is the more
important one, since the jogger should

not devote time to thinking about how
much of it he is wasting. Moreover,
runners should have some form of
support—physical as well as spiritual—and
a beat-up pair of tennis shoes.
Where to Romp
The Johns Hopkins University, besides
being a bastion of academic freedom,
provides many locales for jogging. The
most likely, and therefore the most
boring running area, is the track. For the
purist, a track is either for losing one's
money or watching a multitude of
gentlemen run around in their skivvies.
No, the Natural Jogger must run in the
Jogger's State of Nature: Wyman Park or
the median strip on Charles Street, for
example. The latter is considered part of
the growing trend of Urban Jogging—a
bastardized pr3duct of its noble
predecessor.
Preparations before Running
A famous Greek chef once spoke of"a
healthy mind and a healthy body." Most
joggers have neither attribute—running in
the cold and rain will lead to the latter
and being knocked down by a jogger will

cause the former. Perhaps the most
important preparation is not physical
(warm-up exercises, etc.) but mental.
Above all, the distance runner must
accept pain, yea, relish it. One recent
suggestion involves the use of tape and a
small kettle of scalding water.
Results
Normally, after jogging for a number
of months the participant will have an
improved physique and a more efficient
cardiovascular system. Unfortunately, he
will also suffer from deformed feet as the
cconstant pummeling on a pavement will
transform his toes into a hoof-like
structure.
Not incidentally, the jogger will feel a
sense of accomplishment for becoming
part of a long line of self-deceivers.
The author, a renowned local expert
on jogging, organized the first annual
Greater Baltimore Marathon. A jogging
consultant for several area publications,
his observations on the pastime have
appeared in the Anne Arundel Times, the
Sunday Sun Magazine, and the Dundalk
Review of Books.

The following Point/counterpoint, a
take -off on Wednesday's MSE
Symposium presentation, is based on an
idea by Ken Sokolow.
CBS Point: Shana Alexander
It has become a commonplace among
Practicing journalists that the printed
word is languishing, if it isn't dead
already. Though it may pain some to see _
it happen, the fact is, Jack, that television
Journalism has the advantage of
immediacy and mass appeal. In addition,
the growing sophistication of the TV.
presentations will enable the networks to
capitalize on their built-in advantage of a
vivid graphic medium.
Die-hard apostles of the printed word
such as yourself, Jack, may insist that
newspapers can make up with "color"
and "mood" what they lost in
immediacy, but you're just plain wrong.
Why, no less an authority than David
Halberstam, one of my associates in the
1975 MSE Symposium (to which you
were not invited due to some oversight),
recently asserted that the power of the

television networks makes them "a
veritable opposition party."
Jack, it's nice to hang onto a good
thing, but it's also good to let an old
horse die. The future of journalism iS in
the graphic medium of television, and the
sooner you realize that, Jack, the sooner

you'll be able to make a contribution to
the new wave. The printed word may
survive, Jack, but .it will no longer
flourish.
CBS Counterpoint: James J. Kilpatrick
Shana, despite your expression of
bleeding-heart liberal anxiety over the

fate of the written word, practicing
journalists like myself are daily ensuring
its permanent relevance and dignified
survival.
It will take much more than a few
minutes of electronic blather Sunday
evenings on CBS to change the
wholesome tapestry of influence woven
by responsible—and I want to emphasize
that word RESPONSIBLE—practitioners
of the craft immortalized by William
Allen White, all across this great nation of
ours..
I was not invited to the Milton S.
Eisenhower Symposium, but had I been
there, I would have told those mindlessly
pessimistic, naysaying academic media
junkies a thing or two about the pen as
the sword.
My pen is a sword of truth. My tongue
is a tongue of flame. My Book is the King
James Version of the Bible—the best
example of the everlasting power of the
written word!'

Washington.

Women's strike provokes some new awareness
By D.H. WARREN
had just finished reading about
Women's Strike Day and scratched my
beard a few times, pretending to give the
Whole subject serious consideration. This
was supposed to be a national event, and
even though I try to shut myself off from
the humdrum day-to-day problems by
not watching television or reading daily
papers, I wondered how it was going to
affect me, not to mention the Hop, which
isn't the kind of place where you expect
Strikes or protests or revolutionary
thinking. No, we're all too caught up in
that "pre-professional hysteria." Nothing
like it to make you forget about starving
People, crooked politicians, higher prices,
and all the rest of the garbage that
occupies family dinner tables. Yes, there
are some advantages to being concerned
With no one's future but your own.
However, I digress.
Supposedly, women were even going to
extend their strike to their activity in
-bed. Now, that's intense. I wondered if
Layla was going to go that far. Neither of
us had ever forced sex on the other if he
or she did not want to. And even though
most of my so-called "male
brothers"—and for that matter, the
females,too— won't admit it, men aren't
always horny. At the Hop, anybody will
tell you that if the girls didn't take any
initiative, the boys would still be sitting
around bitching how Hopkins females
never • want to go out. Let's face it, the
American male is basically a very neurotic
creature who has been raised with the
myth that he is superior, and when he
discovers that it ain't necessarily so, he
becomes a shattered ego with terminal
impotence. But I digress.
When I got up the' next morning,
curiosity was on my mind. What was
Women's Strike Day going to be like?
Would there be a lot of feminist bullshit
followed by even worse male bullshit in
my classes? Or would the women just not
go to classes, while men made sly remarks
about their sex lives? I wondered, and
was beginning to really think about it all.
My Morning class had all the women
there. Some small talk went around the
car about the Strike (we were on, a field
trip) and the women didn't seem very
impressed by the whole thing. I figured
they're the kind of people who have
already found their sexual identity and
now have more important things on their
minds. They're distinct individuals who

won't be molded to something called
"men's values" or any other type of
thinking that no longer treats them as
individuals. I was impressed. A woman
is a category. A person is something real.
One , of the guys in the class
mentioned that there was a group of
women in New York City who were
purposely going to fix their husbands'
favorite meals, and be extra nice to
hubby. I don't believe in marriage, at
least not for me. Every time I read
"Rope," by Katherine Anne Porter, I'm
convinced that I am correct. But perhaps
that was how Chose women in New York
found their sexual identity. I felt sorry
for them.
That afternoon at the grocery store, I
noticed several mothers busily shopping
and taking care of their young children. I

suppose they didn't have time to strike. It
would have to be put off until the kids
graduated from college. I had to respect
them. I gave my parents hell when I was
growing up. That's probably why I don't
look forward to having any children.
Some people have got to be parents
though, especially if I want another
generation of readers. There's a situation
that definitely needs improvement. Men
have got to do more than just start the
babies. I decided I was 100 per cent pro
male pregnancies. Once again, though, I
digress.

shopping at the grocery store, also. I
wondered if they were husbands of

store. Or maybe they were just spouses

Hearts of the West: well, not really
By MIKE DEAK
If Hearts of the West, billed as "MGM's
Comedy Surprise," is a comedy, then it's
surprise to me, not because the movie is a
failure, but because of the usual
misleading Hollywood publicity. Hearts
of the West is a droll "coMedy-drama"
(for lack of a better genre) that lingers
like a nostalgic memory in the back of
your mind.
Lewis Tater (perfectly played by Jeff
Bridges) is a dreamy Iowa farmboy who
writes pulp Western stories and aspires to
be like his idol, Zane Grey. He goes out
west to attend the Univeristy of Titan
("nestled qt the foot of silver-veined
mountain's" their brochure reads) to learn
how to be a writer but discovers the
university is only a, series of post office
boxes. Lewis then stumbles his way
through some very ordinary picares'que
adventures (the film's only weakness)and
eventually ends up as a bit player in
Tumbleweed Productions' latest cheap
western.
Working for the movies he meets some
archetypical Hollywood characters. First
there is the director, Kessler (portrayed
with almost anti-Semitic overtones by
Alan Arkin) whose silliness is cleverly
calculated; his penny-pinching bargaining
with the cowboys, his hysterical Yiddish
when directing a terrible fight scene, and
his Knute Rockne-type pep talk he gives
to the cowboys to keep their flagging

spirits up. Arkin plays Kessler so
intensely his performance is funny and
succeeds quite well. He's exactly the son
of a bitch we expect.
Blythe Danner plays Trout, Kessler
script girl. Trout is the kind of girl you
would imagine to be working in
Hollywood at the time, the early thirties.
She's cynical and tough but still an
outsider (the only female in an all-male
production company) trying to wise up
the young inexperience here, later.
Blythe Danner's performance invokes the

By MATT LASKOWSKI
"Angelo, what state do you live in?"
"Uh, Ballamore."
"Angelo, who is the president of the
United States?"
"Prezdent Kennedy."
It's true and it's widespread. Kids need
to be fed information, provoked into
spouting it; they need a • lot of
individualized attention. In the ghetto
some fathers do stay drunk all day and
vent years of frustrations by beating kids.
Some mothers do leave six-year-olds in
charge of sisters and brothers for an
entire working day. But love and honest
parental concern do have a place.
Street-hardened fathers won't allow their
children to be tempered by a similar
environment. They know that it takes
twelve hours of backbreaking work to
keep food on the table. They know what
is lacking; they want a superior
educational opportunity for their
children. Just a chance for their kids to
pull themselves up by President Ford's
"bootstraps." A solid community can
make it work. There are such
communities in Baltimore.
The'elementary schools, the only forte
of the Baltimore public school system,
work to some extent. Little racial strife;
few problems with forced integration,
and a lot of learning. Positive beginnings
for most kids entering school. They offer
a basic standardized curriculum aimed
•
slightly above the capabilities of the
average student. Challenge is present:
certainly not up to par with that at a first
rate county school, but an important
stimulative factor. However, as talented
and enthusiastic as any teacher might be,
there are severe limitations. Large classes,
poor or nonexistent supplies, discipline
and motivational problems bog the
system down. Students aren't even
allowed to take textbooks home in many
instances, aren't encouraged to learn
outside of class. Obviously an alternative
to augment and reinforce this struggling
system is necessary and does presently
exist on a limited scale. There is a
program in which over a hundred and
fifty elementary schoolchildren, from
three radically different neighborhoods,
are individually "tutored"- by local high
school and college students. It's run by
the Office of the Chaplain, and it's the
largest of its kind in Baltimore. It is
invaluable to the kids participating and to
the community they come from: the
ghettos of Baltimore.
Three well-defined geographical areas
are involved: Northwest (Fulton and
Calhoun Streets), Southwest (Franklin
St.), and Eastern (Broadway and Hopkins
Hospital). The make-up of the

neighborhoods vary, some all black, some
a mixture. But the kids have two things in
common: they all are impoverished and
they are willing to spend two afternoons
a week at Hopkins, supplementing their
education—academic and social.
My encounter with this network has
been. as a tutor through the Calhoun
Street Community Center. Immediately
you'll notice a poor black neighborhood,
drunks sleeping on doorsteps, and
colorful .murals on tenement walls. Hope
and desperation side by side. An
uncomfortable feeling will accompany
your introduction to the type of
community where 70 per cent of
Baltimore's blacks live. It is threatening in
a pathetic way.
The Calhoun Center is kids. Two
afternoons a week it's teemir.g with kids.
The Center is a stalwart remnant from the
War on Poverty, that was publicized
extensively in the mid and late sixties.
Federal budget cuts have eliminated two
thirds of the total number of centers. Not
surprisingly, all of the centers that were
connected with the Hopkins tutoring
program remained open. Someone
somewhere determined that these were
the centers most valuable to the
comm unity.
The community knows about the
Hopkins tutoring program. People are
recognized on the street and are

appreciated and in a certain sense
sheltered. The word has spread very
quickly along the local grapevine. No
publicity is necessary, -the good word
spreads from brother to sister to cousin.
The program—an all-volunteer project—is
just able to cope with the numbers
presently involved.
That isn't the whole story of course; in
a metropolitan area this large there are
more than a hundred and fifty kids who
desire and need the attention. There. are
only 50 kids waiting on the community
center lists, hut the word has spread.

City-wide, there is a mounting backlog of
over 400.
It has taken more than ten years to
plant this tentative seed. It finally seems
to be nourishing itself, propagating, and
_even spreading. It's time to graduallY
return control and responsibility to the
communities themselves. The numbers
have exceeded our meager capabilities.
There are adults and older children who
feel the need, and have the basic
knowledge necessary to inspire, motivate,
and uplift. Future Angelos need to know
the details.

Mingling and Explicating in T&S
By RUSS SMITH
Like I was telling Willy, it sure was
lucky that I checked my mailbox
yesterday. It was an afterthought, I
admit, checking the box, but the letter
from the English Department, stuffed
between old Barnstormer solicitations
and Student Council "progress reports,"
confirmed a belief I'll always hang onto:
big things come in small packages.
It wasn't that I hadn't expected good
news from the English Department, but
the invite to the Tudor and Stuart Room
for an informal, but one could be sure
tasteful, gathering of the forty English
majors at Hopkins took me by surprise.
Imagine, I thought, the entire English
Department rallying together for a real
event, everyone invited, undergraduates
too! The lunchroom was abuzz with
rumors that last year's chairman, Ronald
Paulson would be in attendance, possibly
to read from his upcoming work, Hogarth
and Norman Mader: Beyond the Grave
and Across the Centuries.
Invitation in hand, I approached the

musty Victorian confines of the Tudor
and Stuart Room, ready to mingle and
explicate, for a shabby affair this could
not be. Entering the room, I was received
by the current chairman, someone who
isn't exactly a household word but who is
known in literary circles. He was all
smiles as he scarfed down Utz thin
pretzels with one hand, while clutching a
can of National Boh in the other. All
right, I say to myself, so it's not a wine
and cheese affair. That kind of party is
probably dated by now anyway.
But if the refreshments were less than
fitting, the company was fine. Scattered
among the approximately fifteen
students, were not only the blood and
guts of tomorrow's English Department,
the Fergusons, the Michaels, the Wellers,
but smor faculty members as well. The
professors seemed in jubilant spirits as
they introduced themselves to new faces,
pointing with a smile of camaraderie to
the six-packs of beer and bags of cheetos
on the oak table.
The conversation never lagged.

Students, quickly gravitated towards their
favorite prof, in hopes of netting nuggets
about graduate school, and the other
steps on the ladder to an English
professorship. I heard one especially
stimulating exchange between a student
and one of the professors. It only lasted a
couple of minutes, but what they packed
in there, could take a lifetime to study.
Starting with recitations in Old English of
Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, the duo
discussed the pros and cons of Dickens'
later novels, Byron vs. Shelley, and
whether Robinson Crusoe is really the
first English Novel. From the last
question, heated words were almost
sprung, if not for the cool of another
professor, who hushed the matter with an
appropriate quote from Browning.
Sadly, after almost two hours, it was
time to leave. We all agreed that we'd get
together more often. It had worked out
so well, and not one student's smile faded
when one of the professors waved
goodbye and said, "It's been great, see
you next year."

By ALAN HIRSCH
Dr. Lionel Gossman, chairman of
Romance Languages, will leave Hopkins
at the end of the academic year to accept

disclosed yesterday.
Gossman said his decision to leave
Hopkins was a "personal one" and was
not motivated by any dissatisfaction with
the University.
Replacement
Professor Paul Olson has assumed the
Position of acting chairman until a
replacement is chosen.
The Department will probably be
unable to secure a senior faculty
replacement for Gossman until the
1977-'78 academic year, said Dr. Elias
Rivers, chairman of Romance Languages
from 1968 to 1974.
A committee will be formed to search
for a replacement for Gossman and "look
at the whole situation in Romance

Languages," revealed Provost Harry
Woolf.
The departure of an important
person on a faculty automatically brings
you to a crossroads of directions," Woolf
stated.
Gossman said he has recommended to
Woolf an increase in cooperation between
Romance Languages and other
Departments in the University,as well as
the restructuring of the Department's
undergraduate program.
Gossman stated that his decision to
leave Hopkins was based on a desire for a
change in academic environment.
Gossman, on the faculty for 17 years, is
the senior member of Romance
Languages. He began his career as a
teacher here after receiving his doctorate
from Oxford, with a one-year stint on the
faculty at the University of Glasgow in
between.
"I grew up here," remarked Gossman.

"I want to leave my father's house."
"I've no complaint with this
University," commented Gossman. "I've
always been treated fairly. It was a very
difficult decision."
Gossman specializes in 17th and 18th

appointed to a full professorship in 1966,

and became chairman last year.
Gossman said his departure will not
"hurt the Department overly," and more
than anything else, provides a
"momentary feeling of distress."
"It will provide a break in continuity,"
he continued, "but such a break can be
helpful."

As the smoke cleared on the rifle range

Johns Hopkins Varsity Rifle Team came
into view. The team overcame several
obstacles to end up with the largest
membership in over 5 years. Returning
members captured the top five spots in

Beth Terranova (216). Filling out the top
ten are new members Don Gerhart, Bob
Albin, Mike Hearn, Glenn Stewart, and
Tony Moss. These ten shooters have
qualified to participate in the team's first
match today against Dickinson at home.
Problems
"Considering all our problems, I'm
really surprised that so many managed to
stay interested," said one returning
member. "Problems" included the fact
that until a couple weeks ago, the 20 or
so people trying out had to share 5 rifles,
including some privately owned weapons.
The reason for this is that most of the
team's weapons are owned by the JHU
ROTC, and were at Fort Meade for
maintenance. In the meantime, those
wishing to shoot had to use whatever rifle
was available, adjusting equipment and
sights each time.
Team captain Horner explained
further: "Each individual sights in
differently. When you're using the same
weapon all the time, you'll have to make
very few changes once it's been sighted
in. But when you're always changing

weapons, you can spend half your time
just trying to get your sight picture
correct."
The size of the team generated other
problems. For the first time practice
hours had to be assigned to ensure that
everyone who wanted to could get a
chance to shoot. The result was that no
one really had enough time to practice.
John Laczin summed it up: "Constant
and consistent practice is the most
important thing in riflery, as in any sport.
It's just difficult to shoot well when
you're only allowed a couple hours on
one day each week to do it."
Finally, the large number of "recruits"
necessitated the use of returning members
as instructors, cutting even further into
their practice time. "It's probably the
biggest reason for the low scores,"
commented Jeff Booher.
The team's new coach, Captain James
Phillips, was pleased with the large
turnout for the team, and especially glad
to see women coming out. The JHU Rifle
Team \ was the first co-ed sport on
campus, and the first to award varsity
awards to women, and this year saw a
definite pick-up in interest among
Hopkins women.
"In general, I think the team looks
good," said Horner. "In the first few
weeks there've been a lot of good scores,
especially by new members, and there's
been a lot of potential shown. It's hard to
make a season prediction at this point
since we don't know much about the
other teams, but I think we have a really
good chance for another winning season."

By MARC DUVOISIN
Having your car towed is like having
your kidney removed and held at $25
bail—they've got it, you need it, and you
gotta pay to get it back.
The incarceration of motor vehicles is a
relatively recent experiment in the
200-year history of the American penal
system; and an enormously successful
one. The practice was officially instituted
back in the forties by New York Mayor
Fiorello LaGuardia as a means of
controlling the growing traffic congestion
in his metropolis. It was, to say the least,
a horrible comeuppance for the suburban
commuter who would decide, say, to let
the meter run over an extra 10 minutes
while he was negotiating the price of that
bottle of Mateus, and return to find his
parking space vacant.
After the initial stage of thinking his
car stolen or lost, he realized what had
happened. And after the secondary stage
of outrage at having his vehicle abducted,
he began to think what a long walk it
would be back across the Hudson and,
like as not, took a bus downtown to pay
his dues. For about a decade, New York
devoted a full square mile on Welfare
Island to housing towed cars, so large
were the daily heists. Not only did the
traffic congestion get better, but the city
was able to avert God knows how many
budget deficits—all due to the towing
business.
Other cities took the cue therefrom
and,by that process we call specialization,
made the penalty of towing an effective
and fear-inspiring caveat. In metropolises

"Tow-Away Zones" like the plague.

the computer that got me.

you just don't pay out of state parking

reciprocate—everybody knows that.
Those Jersey plates were a free pass

The finer points of road-running
By JAN HAMMERMAN
I first engaged in the activity of jogging
at age seven, upon catching sight of my
father with a belt in hand . This pioneer
effort failed miserably, however, because
my shoestrings were too long and because
Nature called at a most inopportune
moment. Be that as it may. My premier
attempt at competitive running also
proved somewhat less that successful—a
third-place finish to a shnoozer puppy
and the neighborhood para'plegic in the
annual Block party.
Unperturbed, undaunted, and slightly
crazy, I joined my high school
cross-country team with hopes of earning
a varsity letter to put on a cross-country
sweatshirt which would be worn over a
cross-country T-shirt. All three objectives
were realized. In addition, I cam? in
156th in Baltimore County, improving 3
notches after bringing up the rear a
season earlier.
Jogging demands that the participant
have two legs and as little common sense
as possible. The last feature is the more
important one, since the jogger should

not devote time to thinking about how
much of it he is wasting. Moreover,
runners should have some form of
support—physical as well as spiritual—and
a beat-up pair of tennis shoes.
Where to Romp
The Johns Hopkins University, besides
being a bastion of academic freedom,
provides many locales for jogging. The
most likely, and therefore the most
boring running area, is the track. For the
purist, a track is either for losing one's
money or watching a multitude of
gentlemen run around in their skivvies.
No, the Natural Jogger must run in the
Jogger's State of Nature: Wyman Park or
the median strip on Charles Street, for
example. The latter is considered part of
the growing trend of Urban Jogging—a
bastardized pr3duct of its noble
predecessor.
Preparations before Running
A famous Greek chef once spoke of"a
healthy mind and a healthy body." Most
joggers have neither attribute—running in
the cold and rain will lead to the latter
and being knocked down by a jogger will

cause the former. Perhaps the most
important preparation is not physical
(warm-up exercises, etc.) but mental.
Above all, the distance runner must
accept pain, yea, relish it. One recent
suggestion involves the use of tape and a
small kettle of scalding water.
Results
Normally, after jogging for a number
of months the participant will have an
improved physique and a more efficient
cardiovascular system. Unfortunately, he
will also suffer from deformed feet as the
cconstant pummeling on a pavement will
transform his toes into a hoof-like
structure.
Not incidentally, the jogger will feel a
sense of accomplishment for becoming
part of a long line of self-deceivers.
The author, a renowned local expert
on jogging, organized the first annual
Greater Baltimore Marathon. A jogging
consultant for several area publications,
his observations on the pastime have
appeared in the Anne Arundel Times, the
Sunday Sun Magazine, and the Dundalk
Review of Books.

By MIKE DEAK
If Hearts of the West, billed as "MGM's
Comedy Surprise," is a comedy, then it's
surprise to me, not because the movie is a
failure, but because of the usual
misleading Hollywood publicity. Hearts
of the West is a droll "coMedy-drama"
(for lack of a better genre) that lingers
like a nostalgic memory in the back of
your mind.
Lewis Tater (perfectly played by Jeff
Bridges) is a dreamy Iowa farmboy who
writes pulp Western stories and aspires to
be like his idol, Zane Grey. He goes out
west to attend the Univeristy of Titan
("nestled qt the foot of silver-veined
mountain's" their brochure reads) to learn
how to be a writer but discovers the
university is only a, series of post office
boxes. Lewis then stumbles his way
through some very ordinary picares'que
adventures (the film's only weakness)and
eventually ends up as a bit player in
Tumbleweed Productions' latest cheap
western.
Working for the movies he meets some
archetypical Hollywood characters. First
there is the director, Kessler (portrayed
with almost anti-Semitic overtones by
Alan Arkin) whose silliness is cleverly
calculated; his penny-pinching bargaining
with the cowboys, his hysterical Yiddish
when directing a terrible fight scene, and
his Knute Rockne-type pep talk he gives
to the cowboys to keep their flagging

spirits up. Arkin plays Kessler so
intensely his performance is funny and
succeeds quite well. He's exactly the son
of a bitch we expect.
Blythe Danner plays Trout, Kessler
script girl. Trout is the kind of girl you
would imagine to be working in
Hollywood at the time, the early thirties.
She's cynical and tough but still an
outsider (the only female in an all-male
production company) trying to wise up
the young inexperience here, later.
Blythe Danner's performance invokes the
ghosts of Jean Arthur trying to initiate
Jimmy Stewart and Gary Cooper in "Mr.
Smith Goes to Washington'. and "Mr.
Deeds Goes to Town," two of the most
popular movies of the decade.
Father-Figure
As Howard Pike, an aging cowboy
actor, Andy Griffith shows for the first
time in a long while that he is a very
capable actor. His performance mocks the
hokey sheriff he played on his own
television show but echoes back to his
stunning screen debut in Kazan's "A Face
in the Crowd" when he played a country
singer elevated to a tragic demagogue.
There is a certain sad, nostalgic
ruggedness ingrained in his face that
makes him the perfect father-figure to
Lewis which inevitably leads to cruel
disillusionment.
All these characters are, to use a
Hollywood cliche, memorable, and the

only thing wrong is that we see too little
of them. The picaresque adventures I
mentioned before limit the film to a
rather tedious plot that is irrelevant to
the theme. The film centers on Lewis'
realization of the truth about Western
myths. He realizes the Western is not
overblown reality but desperate creations
of men more concerned with money than
ideals. To Lewis, Westerns are not what
they're cracked up to be.

Rotunda, this weekend Once Is Not
Enough, typical Jacqueline Susann trash,
is playing at the other Rotunda cinema.
Over at the Boulevard ($1.50 at all times)
is,a re-release of last year's most overrated
picture, The Godfather—Part II. And on

Boorman's typical post-Clockwork
Orange science fiction flick, Zardoz,
which has a gigantic head spitting out
guns and Sean Connery trapezing about
with only. a loin cloth to hide his 'shame.
On Saturday night Between Time and
Timbuktu will take the place of Zardoz
and I think it's a waste of money to see
it. Several Kurt Vonnegut characters are
thrown together in one horrible mulligan
stew that could be called Kurt Through
the Looking Glass. The only good point is
Bob and Ray as two television
commentators doing a nasty parody of
Walter Cronkite and Wally Shirra, getting
what they deserved.

Tutoring program's seed begins to sprout
By MATT LASKOWSKI
"Angelo, what state do you live in?"
"Uh, Ballamore."
"Angelo, who is the president of the
United States?"
"Prezdent Kennedy."
It's true and it's widespread. Kids need
to be fed information, provoked into
spouting it; they need a • lot of
individualized attention. In the ghetto
some fathers do stay drunk all day and
vent years of frustrations by beating kids.
Some mothers do leave six-year-olds in
charge of sisters and brothers for an
entire working day. But love and honest
parental concern do have a place.
Street-hardened fathers won't allow their
children to be tempered by a similar
environment. They know that it takes
twelve hours of backbreaking work to
keep food on the table. They know what
is lacking; they want a superior
educational opportunity for their
children. Just a chance for their kids to
pull themselves up by President Ford's
"bootstraps." A solid community can
make it work. There are such
communities in Baltimore.
The'elementary schools, the only forte
of the Baltimore public school system,
work to some extent. Little racial strife;
few problems with forced integration,
and a lot of learning. Positive beginnings
for most kids entering school. They offer
a basic standardized curriculum aimed
•
slightly above the capabilities of the
average student. Challenge is present:
certainly not up to par with that at a first
rate county school, but an important
stimulative factor. However, as talented
and enthusiastic as any teacher might be,
there are severe limitations. Large classes,
poor or nonexistent supplies, discipline
and motivational problems bog the
system down. Students aren't even
allowed to take textbooks home in many
instances, aren't encouraged to learn
outside of class. Obviously an alternative
to augment and reinforce this struggling
system is necessary and does presently
exist on a limited scale. There is a
program in which over a hundred and
fifty elementary schoolchildren, from
three radically different neighborhoods,
are individually "tutored"- by local high
school and college students. It's run by
the Office of the Chaplain, and it's the
largest of its kind in Baltimore. It is
invaluable to the kids participating and to
the community they come from: the
ghettos of Baltimore.
Three well-defined geographical areas
are involved: Northwest (Fulton and
Calhoun Streets), Southwest (Franklin
St.), and Eastern (Broadway and Hopkins
Hospital). The make-up of the

neighborhoods vary, some all black, some
a mixture. But the kids have two things in
common: they all are impoverished and
they are willing to spend two afternoons
a week at Hopkins, supplementing their
education—academic and social.
My encounter with this network has
been. as a tutor through the Calhoun
Street Community Center. Immediately
you'll notice a poor black neighborhood,
drunks sleeping on doorsteps, and
colorful .murals on tenement walls. Hope
and desperation side by side. An
uncomfortable feeling will accompany
your introduction to the type of
community where 70 per cent of
Baltimore's blacks live. It is threatening in
a pathetic way.
The Calhoun Center is kids. Two
afternoons a week it's teemir.g with kids.
The Center is a stalwart remnant from the
War on Poverty, that was publicized
extensively in the mid and late sixties.
Federal budget cuts have eliminated two
thirds of the total number of centers. Not
surprisingly, all of the centers that were
connected with the Hopkins tutoring
program remained open. Someone
somewhere determined that these were
the centers most valuable to the
comm unity.
The community knows about the
Hopkins tutoring program. People are
recognized on the street and are

appreciated and in a certain sense
sheltered. The word has spread very
quickly along the local grapevine. No
publicity is necessary, -the good word
spreads from brother to sister to cousin.
The program—an all-volunteer project—is
just able to cope with the numbers
presently involved.
That isn't the whole story of course; in
a metropolitan area this large there are
more than a hundred and fifty kids who
desire and need the attention. There. are
only 50 kids waiting on the community
center lists, hut the word has spread.

City-wide, there is a mounting backlog of
over 400.
It has taken more than ten years to
plant this tentative seed. It finally seems
to be nourishing itself, propagating, and
_even spreading. It's time to graduallY
return control and responsibility to the
communities themselves. The numbers
have exceeded our meager capabilities.
There are adults and older children who
feel the need, and have the basic
knowledge necessary to inspire, motivate,
and uplift. Future Angelos need to know
the details.

Mingling and Explicating in T&S
By RUSS SMITH
Like I was telling Willy, it sure was
lucky that I checked my mailbox
yesterday. It was an afterthought, I
admit, checking the box, but the letter
from the English Department, stuffed
between old Barnstormer solicitations
and Student Council "progress reports,"
confirmed a belief I'll always hang onto:
big things come in small packages.
It wasn't that I hadn't expected good
news from the English Department, but
the invite to the Tudor and Stuart Room
for an informal, but one could be sure
tasteful, gathering of the forty English
majors at Hopkins took me by surprise.
Imagine, I thought, the entire English
Department rallying together for a real
event, everyone invited, undergraduates
too! The lunchroom was abuzz with
rumors that last year's chairman, Ronald
Paulson would be in attendance, possibly
to read from his upcoming work, Hogarth
and Norman Mader: Beyond the Grave
and Across the Centuries.
Invitation in hand, I approached the

musty Victorian confines of the Tudor
and Stuart Room, ready to mingle and
explicate, for a shabby affair this could
not be. Entering the room, I was received
by the current chairman, someone who
isn't exactly a household word but who is
known in literary circles. He was all
smiles as he scarfed down Utz thin
pretzels with one hand, while clutching a
can of National Boh in the other. All
right, I say to myself, so it's not a wine
and cheese affair. That kind of party is
probably dated by now anyway.
But if the refreshments were less than
fitting, the company was fine. Scattered
among the approximately fifteen
students, were not only the blood and
guts of tomorrow's English Department,
the Fergusons, the Michaels, the Wellers,
but smor faculty members as well. The
professors seemed in jubilant spirits as
they introduced themselves to new faces,
pointing with a smile of camaraderie to
the six-packs of beer and bags of cheetos
on the oak table.
The conversation never lagged.

Students, quickly gravitated towards their
favorite prof, in hopes of netting nuggets
about graduate school, and the other
steps on the ladder to an English
professorship. I heard one especially
stimulating exchange between a student
and one of the professors. It only lasted a
couple of minutes, but what they packed
in there, could take a lifetime to study.
Starting with recitations in Old English of
Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, the duo
discussed the pros and cons of Dickens'
later novels, Byron vs. Shelley, and
whether Robinson Crusoe is really the
first English Novel. From the last
question, heated words were almost
sprung, if not for the cool of another
professor, who hushed the matter with an
appropriate quote from Browning.
Sadly, after almost two hours, it was
time to leave. We all agreed that we'd get
together more often. It had worked out
so well, and not one student's smile faded
when one of the professors waved
goodbye and said, "It's been great, see
you next year."

Dr. Gossman to leave Hopkins for Princeton
By ALAN HIRSCH
Dr. Lionel Gossman, chairman of
Romance Languages, will leave Hopkins
at the end of the academic year to accept
a position at Princeton University, he
disclosed yesterday.
Gossman said his decision to leave
Hopkins was a "personal one" and was
not motivated by any dissatisfaction with
the University.
Replacement
Professor Paul Olson has assumed the
Position of acting chairman until a
replacement is chosen.
The Department will probably be
unable to secure a senior faculty
replacement for Gossman until the
1977-'78 academic year, said Dr. Elias
Rivers, chairman of Romance Languages
from 1968 to 1974.
A committee will be formed to search
for a replacement for Gossman and "look
at the whole situation in Romance

Languages," revealed Provost Harry
Woolf.
The departure of an important
person on a faculty automatically brings
you to a crossroads of directions," Woolf
stated.
Gossman said he has recommended to
Woolf an increase in cooperation between
Romance Languages and other
Departments in the University,as well as
the restructuring of the Department's
undergraduate program.
Gossman stated that his decision to
leave Hopkins was based on a desire for a
change in academic environment.
Gossman, on the faculty for 17 years, is
the senior member of Romance
Languages. He began his career as a
teacher here after receiving his doctorate
from Oxford, with a one-year stint on the
faculty at the University of Glasgow in
between.
"I grew up here," remarked Gossman.

"I want to leave my father's house."
"I've no complaint with this
University," commented Gossman. "I've
always been treated fairly. It was a very
difficult decision."
Gossman specializes in 17th and 18th
Century French Literature. He was
appointed to a full professorship in 1966,

and became chairman last year.
Gossman said his departure will not
"hurt the Department overly," and more
than anything else, provides a
"momentary feeling of distress."
"It will provide a break in continuity,"
he continued, "but such a break can be
helpful."

miss the game Saturday, in addition to
linebacker John Nutting and fullback
Peter Bussey, both of whom are out for
the season.
Changes
Hopkins coach Dennis Cox has made
.a number of position changes to help fill
the vacated spots and bolster his offense.
"Our lack of depth is finally having an
effect with all the injuries, but we've
taught all the players to play more than
one position just in case something like
this happened. It won't be the first time
they're playing at the position," he said.
Nick Fletcher, Doober Aburn, and
Jack Deckelbaum will all get work in the

fullback slot. Tom Bender has been
moved from safety to quarterback, being
replaced by Mike Rhodey at safety, and
former quarterback Dave Emala has been
shifted to wingback to utilize his "good
hands" as a receiver. Also, Charles Hauck
has been moved from tackle to
linebacker.
Physically, both teams are almost
identical. Neither team is particularly big,
each boasting their largest linemen at
only around 215 pounds, and the player
weights at each position are similar.
Statistically, on offense, average total
offense is within one yard per game, with
Hopkins sporting an edge in rushing and
Moravian showing an edge in passing.
The most substantial difference
between the two combatants has been on
defense and this category may prove to
be the deciding factor. The Blue Jays,
with a 1-3-1 record, have yielded 105
more points than they've scored.
Moravian, 2-2-1 this season, has scored 15
more points than it has allowed. In
addition, the Moravian yards-per-game
allowance has been 75 yards lower than
that of the Blue Jays.
